title: Preseason Open Forum [day 3]

embed.description: What a time. You've read the sites, you've seen the devblogs , you've heard the announcements. Preseason is finally upon us. So what's on the docket for us this year? Well, to be frank, a little bit ofeverything. We're looking to make every game of League feels unique, and that means going the distance to make sure your decisions matter.

body:
I just realized I've been linking the OCE patch notes. Hah. Anyway...

You've survived the patch notes.

You've read the dev blogs.

**You've played a few games in the preseason!**  *And you didn't forget your masteries*.

We're going to be chilling in the dev corner this week to talk about any of the preseason changes coming in the patch. Hopefully by tomorrow you'll also have a few games under your belt.

Also: *you're not here to pose opinions as questions.*

replies.body:
Mordekaiser's has officially been dethroned as the terror of bot lane due to Caitlyn holding him hostage with her headshots, graves outpushing and outbursting him, Corki and Koggles shredding him like aluminum foil.
This is all made worse by his really, really, really bad base armor of 20.

I personally didn't even like duo lane Morde but will this loss of power be seized to give him some more power, especially in solo lanes.
Something a lot of Mordekaiser fans really wanted.
The marksmen changes actually evicted him from his supposed "home" bot so what's your stance on Morde's future?

Still, preseason is a scary place but it's already evident that he'll be a pain to actually tweak o_O

This is certainly an opinion posed as a question. That said, I'm curious if this is absolutely true or if Mordekaiser was just used to not having all of these bullies show up in lane. Caitlyn is definitely his antithesis and requires him to play very differently than vs. most other marksmen. Rather than taking direct intervention, I'm curious if there needs to be a real adjustment period first.
Have you considered putting some kind of CC immunity on Morde? Like during his W, he can't be slowed or rooted. Doesn't give mobility, doesn't give CC but could address some of his problems.
Gosh no. It's bad enough on Olaf who can't deal upwards of 1k damage on one spell without building much offense.
this is classic rework -> op on release ->3 patchs of nerfs -> " oh , his shinning moment is gone " -> forggotten

>you're not here to pose opinions as questions.

So...you don´t want your players opinions on your game?

I mean, most of the important questions usually should lead to both sides reflecting their positions. But if you only accept questions that don´t voice any sort of opinion it´s just very basic information without reflecting anything. It´s basically politcs/promotion - but not a discussion. So what´s the point of having that? you could just write a FAQ per day and it´ll be less work to achieve the same.

When I engage in a meaningful dialogue that spits out real actionable feedback, I don't start with my opinion. I lead with questions to ensure the feedback I'm giving is actually in line with the values we may or may not share.

For example, my mother used to hound me every day about becoming a doctor. She'd ask me, "Why aren't you taking this class, don't you want to be a doctor?" or "If you're going to be a doctor, you shouldn't do that." It got to the point where she had a mini-intervention with me to discuss why I wasn't listening to her feedback. At that point I had to tell her I wanted to be a writer and had been shaping my life according to that. After a year of convincing, she finally came around and then her suggestions and feedback actually made sense - "Why not take this job instead, if you want to be a writer?"

In this context, if you come in and say "why didn't you nerf Yasuo before this patch?" that presumes many, many things and makes it nearly impossible to engage. We have to defuse your argument based on your values before coming to our own values. The moment that happens, you say "no, ensuring the balance of Yasuo should the #1 most important thing to your team," and we have to revisit why that may not be the case.

On the flip side, I'm trying - and our designers are trying - not to also lead with opinions but to ask why you might be scared or concerned about something. It could be there's a deeper reason and we can adjust for that, rather than the superficial one. Finally, all of these guys have years and years of experience working on games, and they draw from those for their own conclusions. Most players - and this is a blanket statement - draw from their very personal experience. No player is 'worried' about the holistic fun of the game. They are only worried about their experience and how much fun they have. The values there are already different.

So yes, we like your opinions and your feedback, and we are actively seeking it. That shouldn't be where the conversation begins though.

If your intentions are so pure, then you should know that every time you say that phrase about questions and opinions, it doesn't come off the way you mean it. It comes off as condescending and rude. It comes off as Riot saying the player's opinion doesn't matter, that the player isn't here to question Riot's decisions, and that the player can only ask basic, informational questions about what is going on.

I think if you're looking for condescension, you can find it anywhere, but I'll take that into consideration sorry. I can be snarky but I don't worry about tempering it because I assume you know my intentions are good. If you don't think so and want to call me an asshole, that's also fine and I'll think about how to work around it. That said, I'm also not in the business of being nice to everyone. I just want to have a conversation about the game I love and I want to enable others to do the same.

Thank you. It would be appreciated. A lot of players, including myself, don't necessarily have that trust in Riot. Trusting someone's decision making because of their intentions is a poor choice because the two are not linked; the ability to make a good decision over a bad one is not the same as the ability to know which decision is good and which is bad. A lot of us have especially been burned by ChampUp, where trusting someone's intentions can leave a champ in a poor state for months and months.

Since you want us to outline our assumptions before we ask questions, I'll lay out mine. I proceed under the assumption that the general balance between AP and AD has been fairly good for the past couple of seasons. Mages were seen. ADCs were always seen. We are a ways from league of cleavers. The efficiency-pass through that has functionally buffed AD and functionally nerfed AP occurred because I believe Riot said that AP items were very efficient. Where is the disconnect here? That seems (and appears to be born out) a sure-fire way to put the game in a state of imbalance.

>  I proceed under the assumption that the general balance between AP and AD has been fairly good for the past couple of seasons.

I don't believe this is true once you look at it under the lens of game impact.

Consider the consistent player sentiment across seasons: Your mid-lane is incredibly impactful and likely carries your game. AD carries are frustrating when fully farmed but feel like they lack agency throughout most of the game.

While players have brought up several decent reasons for why this is true (scaling / the impact of mid-lane) - it seems very likely that this effect could also be simply produced by the fact that, on a raw gold basis - mages were simply getting more out of early gold.

The other portion of this that I typically struggle with is that **class** imbalances tends to be a matter of perspective more so than actual balance.  

That is, people have a view of how the mage vs. carry fight should play out.  This view can be significantly different from player to player but because each class is more -or- less mandatory - class imbalances are largely unaffected by win-rate until they start completely replacing the core functions of another class. 

(For example, Cleaver made AP obsolete - because you no longer needed mixed damage to function well.  Likewise, any super melee hybrid defense/offense meta tends to make ranged entirely obsolete.)

Therefore, whatever the current state of the game is **tends** to be perceived as good from a class balance perspective - whether it's true or not.

> That seems (and appears to be born out) a sure-fire way to put the game in a state of imbalance.

Luckily, due to some of the above factors, class imbalances are actually fairly robust to changes like this as the change needs to be extreme enough to make it so that another class can replace said class entirely.

Because most classes have a core function that is very difficult to replace - classes tend to have a lot more 'sticking' power even when the class in question is factually weak.  The prevailing thought among the AD curve currently is that the previous ADC curves are weak but mandatory - and thus, despite needing to pick both an AD and an AP carry - their respective power relative to one another is one forged from necessity of mixed damage types and tower sieging rather than actual balance between their power ratios.

That is, because ADC's aren't optional - you can make them as weak as you can - people will still bring them due to sieging.  Like-wise with the support/tank etc.  Therefore, you can be in a state where AP is incredibly strong and AD incredibly weak and still see a high prevalence of AP vs. AD.

Likewise - you can't stack damage sources of a single type and expect to get away with it - thus some source of magic damage will always be required.

That's not to say that this state is good or anything - just that it tends to be harder to change.

ADCs shouldn't get agency if they're keeping their high end power.

Yeah, I realize that's rough to say, but it's true. If I'm fighting an ADC that can peel for himself AND has the damage to 1v4/5 us, that's a broken champion.

Agreed, directionally speaking.

Reinboom's goals on the ADC itemization specifically was to lower their high-end power - they spent a lot of time running through damage curves to ensure that for most soft targets, time to kill was higher overall.

Part of this is accomplished by making their power increase items narrower (See: Giant Slayer, Bonus Pen, etc.) while some of it was just lowering their maximum potential AD from most items (IE line, etc.)

Whether we've hit the mark on that, time will tell - will likely be lots of tuning in the future.
The 1v4 my enemy Lucian had last game with IE, ER, BT, Lord Domonik's, and Runaan's, while simultaniously being impossible to hit, would disagree with you.

Not disagree'ing that the current tuning may be way off - but that was the intent.

That said, this wouldn't be the first time that Lucian has single-handedly gotten his entire class nerfed - a distinction he shares with Caitlyn and Vayne. :P

He uses items really well.

Honestly?

Just stop giving ADCs low cooldown dashes.

Everyone is happier that way.
Well, can you please tackle that problem at the root, then? Making him use items less well?

I honestly fundamentally disagree with a lot of your reasoning. I agree that ADCs aren't optional but would say that there is no other class besides ADC that can't be replaced by something else. We have had League of Assassins where there wasn't a Mage in sight. You can replace tanks with disengage (you can't lump tanks and Janna together in the same group like you kind of implied by saying support/tank). You can replace AP mages with wholesale with assassins (generally AD) or even caster ADCs like Varus in the mid lane. You cannot replace ADCs because as you noted they are needed for tower destruction. It's just not true that other classes have sticking power. And I don't think ADCs can ever be satisfactory until they are replaceable. There needs to be a trade-off made. Every class in LoL has an effect that can be replicated or mitigated by choosing a different class except for ADCs. Mages poke, lock down, burst. All of those effects can be replicated to lesser or greater degrees by other roles. No other role takes towers.

 **Mages are not the same thing as mid lane.** Mid is influential because it is, literally, mid. In the geography of the map, the middle lane controls positional access to each side. Knock down the mid tower and the enemy jungle is open. No change to ADCs will change this. The player in mid - either assassin Mage or Yasuo - is able to roam top or bot because of their geography. No change to ADCs short of allowing them to pick teleport will stop this. The player in the middle lane *should* be the more impactful because their performance has a larger impact on the overall strategic flow of the game.

I fundamentally don't think that ADCs should not have much agency because the dream of 1v5 is an unhealthy one. They should always be reliant on their teams. They are supposed to be the sustained damage dealer. They should only have high damage output over extended periods of time. They should not be duelists - dueling requires either burst damage or a way to avoid damage, both of which increase agency. There should not be a point in any game where the ADC just has enough gold to kill everything. Mage agency beyond unloading a combo - once they are on cooldown they have to run. ADC players don't feel the same pressure because autoattacks are essentially always up. Because they don't have that same moment of real powerlessness that is a Mage fully on cooldown, they don't feel like they need to rely on their team the same way. ADCs need clearer windows to feel agency.

EDIT: a rephrase I thought of that is perhaps a hit clearer: ADC players might not feel much agency because I doubt many of them see tower taking as their primary job. They probably see their primary job as killing everything in the fight. Since they are the only class that can take towers, they will always revolve around this fact. If an identity isn't replaceable then they are balanced to some degree around this lowest common denominator. They need to have clear multiple roles that don't just involve killing everything (because that's not a healthy fantasy for the other players in the game) and be the only class that can take towers (because that limits what else they can be allowed to do).

First of all, thanks for the reply!

>On the flip side, I'm trying - and our designers are trying - not to also lead with opinions but to ask why you might be scared or concerned about something. It could be there's a deeper reason and we can adjust for that, rather than the superficial one. Finally, all of these guys have years and years of experience working on games, and they draw from those for their own conclusions. Most players - and this is a blanket statement - draw from their very personal experience. No player is 'worried' about the holistic fun of the game. They are only worried about their experience and how much fun they have. The values there are already different.

I think we´re having two fundamental issues here from my position:

- the definition of opinion - for me it´s having one´s own mind and doing what you want your designers apparently do - draw an informed (based on ones best knowledge/experience) conclusion - or statement of such. This also means most questions that actually contain value usually also contain an opinion of sorts (as most informed questions stem from experience/knowledge and not just to fill a void from my point of view). So i agree that leading with opinions would in fact be tyranny of sorts - instead i think it´s important to voice ones opinions and listen to others to then maybe reflect upon it and find a consensus. So opinion sort of is the beginning of all conversation - if you don´t have any opinions, how would you be able to reflect upon an answer in the first place?

- While players usually draw from their personal experience - for a lot of players this refers to more than a decade of gaming, so it´s a rather vast experience - and ultimatly most designers can only do the same (sure, they are a little more informed about the design in general and underlying issues - but the goal for both is most of the times the same - to create a great game that is fun to play - as a whole, not only because abusing a single champ might be fun for a week). You´ll find badly informed decissions on both sides, but all in all i think there´s a lot of valuable feedback from playerside (though sometimes hidden in a lot of frustration)...and not much of it seems to get the attention it deserves, if any at all.

So I think where the misinterpretation stems from - and I can correct in the future - is between having an opinion or enforcing an opinion.

The sentiment I'm going for with "no opinions as questions" is more along the lines of: please don't make demands, or frame demands as questions, because that's not a discussion, that's a negotiation.

I would love for people to have opinions and to present them with the intention of discussion, rather than the intention of hostility. I know that some people don't intend for that but still come off as hostile, but that's where education comes in. I won't just abide by "well, just answer the question" because if you've seen any of Greg's (Ghostcrawler) discussions, they often start out hostile and aggressive while he mediates. I just don't think that's healthy and it doesn't teach anyone manners.

So we agree that opinions are good, and I like opinions that want to be challenged or investigated. I'll clarify that rather than be snarky.

For the second point, I see your point but I'll challenge you on the concept of mindfulness. As a player, I am focused on my desires, my wants, and what makes a fun game **to me**. I love action games with any form of customizatin or progression, I love deep RPGs, I am getting used to CCGs, I dislike straight action games like Super Meat Boy but I believe it's a fantastic game for what it is.

With a game like League, people like it for a variety of reasons and I want to make those reasons clear and understood by all parties before we get to discussion. We all want to create a great game that's fun - but League is fun to us in different ways. I love the combination of strategic and tactical elements, but some people just want to sit top and beat the shit out of someone. That's a lens.

So yes people can draw from their experiences and talk about their desires in relation to their experiences - I love that. I think not everyone is trained or used to examining why they love what they love, or what lies behind their enjoyment of a game. Designers spend years thinking about this, and it is definitely a learned trait that is honed over years.

> [{quoted}](name=Riot Pwyff,realm=NA,application-id=A7LBtoKc,discussion-id=ZzAaElGY,comment-id=0008000200020000,timestamp=2015-11-13T00:18:45.624+0000)
 I just don't think that's healthy and it doesn't teach anyone manners.

Why are you trying to teach us manners?  
Why don't you just talk about the game instead, friendo?

Because human decency and respect are the most important things to establishing a healthy relationship for the future. We can talk about the game but there needs to be mutual respect, not someone coming in and holding a conversation hostage until they get the outcome they want.

I understand passion and allow it. 

What I won't allow is for someone to be flat-out rude. I also fundamentally disagree that this is the standard way of the internet. It shouldn't be and we have the opportunity to change that.

If you disagree, we can agree to disagree but I'm the one trying to drive a conversation.

I 100% agree that being a jerk should not be the standard of the internet.  I do disagree with the mentality that League is a giant social experiment for people to try and change the behavior of people on the internet (albeit for the better).  
There needs to be mutual respect for a conversation, this is true.  So respond to the people that show the respect you ask for, don't blow up the red feed with posts about how people are mean on the internet.  I want to see red posts in this thread about the preseason, not Lyte-esque tone policing.
"what I wont allow"
"it doesnt teach anyone manners"
It's stuff like this that upsets people.  I'm sure I am coming off as a real jerk right now, and I want you to know this is not personal, just my feedback posed as a statement that is an opinion.

I don't really get offended even if people are being jerks or not, by the way. I get what you're saying and in this conversation I don't really need to recalibrate what's respectful. It takes a lot to offend me or even bother me on the internet.

Anyway, this isn't a giant social experiment to teach people to be better people for the sake of it.

I'm doing this because I believe I have the right as an individual to say "I would like to be treated with respect" and I also reserve the right to call anyone out if they try to violate it for their own intentions. In return, I will do the same. 

Yes we can only respond to the respectful questions and answers, but if someone's going to yell in the background "hey fuck you why the fuck can't you nerf Yasuo you stupid fucks," I will firmly beat the shit out of it. No questions. That kid can go to his friends and say the same thing and I won't bat an eye. He can go to reddit and do the same and I won't care. It's just that I know my time is worth something - as is yours - and if someone doesn't respect that I want to ensure it doesn't happen again to me.

I'm not on a crusade to fix the internet. I won't seek it out. That said, if someone posts in a conversation thread like this, I assume they are aiming it at us (or me) and want us (or myself) to read it. If it's written in a rude way intended to be mean 'for the sake being mean' or to prove a point, I want to actively shape my environment.

I'm tone policying for mutual respect because it's necessary to make conversations like these scalable so they don't burn people out.

In all honesty, I'm setting these parameters because it's so fucking easy to burn out on the internet, and I don't want us to go silent again.

Totally agreed with everything you were posting and was with you up until the last line. I really dislike how rioters always passive aggressively threaten not posting anymore every time they have a heated discussion with someone and get frustrated. I'm so with you on everything else though. I just don't think rioters consistently telling the community 'some of you are jerks and therefore I don't want to post' is doing anything but making everyone feel bad. Every time I see it makes me hate this community more and want to be part of it less and less.

And while it's easy to say hey don't do it treat me with respect. Everyone loses their head sometimes and posts overly aggressive posts on issues that they've felt have been persistent and ignored and bottling up inside them. This is an inevitable fact of human psychology. For every angry guy there's also 1000 guys who love it when you post.

tldr; Stand up for yourself when someone does post an overly emotional angry response, but don't expect it not to happen or threaten red silence.

I think you extracted a far-reaching conclusion, actually! I'm not saying "we're going to go silent because y'all were mean" it's not a threat. It's just that for some it's easy to keep trucking and beating the shit out of bullies on the internet. For others, it's wearisome and borderline inevitable that you dread going out there.

I don't want a hostile work environment and it's not a threat, it's a fact that it can become it. Look at the front page of the boards right now. I'm saying that's a lion's den and I don't want our conversations to become that because even the thickest skinned individual will peace the fuck out.

No threats and I don't think I've ever seen a Rioter try to win a conversation "or else they'll go silent."

No they don't say that at all it's passive. "people are abusive it makes it hard to be motivated to reply on the boards", "its easy to burn out when .." etc. **To which I totally agree**, no one wants to come to a place where people are just going to abuse them all the time. Which is why I'm all for telling people to shut their mouths when they're being over the top. 

But bringing that up every time someone loses their head at you doesn't really do much for my morale. It's like all the work that the vast majority of people spend having great conversations with you guys is overshadowed by a few emotional hot heads and if even you can't stand to talk to this community for extended periods of time without being burnt out what does that say for us as a whole?

Just my 2c. Do with it what you will.

>So I think where the misinterpretation stems from - and I can correct in the future - is between having an opinion or enforcing an opinion.

yea, guess Schleiermacher had been sort of right claiming that the regular situation of all conversation is missunderstanding...which is why we need dialogues/discussions in the first place \*smiles*

>For the second point, I see your point but I'll challenge you on the concept of mindfulness. [...] Designers spend years thinking about this, and it is definitely a learned trait that is honed over years.

well yea, i think right now for me personally it´s sort of hard to grasp what your design intends are for League as a moba.
What I did love so far for mobas, especially league is that those games are strategically insanly deep (makro-game), while still offering a lot of action (mikro-game) - though with the latest changes it feels like you really got rid of most strategic aspects just for more or less random snowballing (to some degree that has always been an issue in SoloQ, but really not in it´s current form). So not really knowing what you yourself want to achieve sort of makes it a little hard to give you the feedback you´d need - leaving a lot of vague formulated anecdotes about what feels fun and what doesn´t. 
So well, while i believe it might be really hard to fish for good advice in an infinite ocean of player-opinions...maybe a little more clarity from your side could go a long way here? 
t´s fine and nice to let the community ask questions about anything, but ultimatly i think it´s not all that enlightening - so why don´t you try it the other way and ask the community about more specific feedback on things you struggle with (or are proud of)? - I don´t think it hurts to not only have the developer perspective but also see the game a little more with the actual players eyes (and even if you ultimatly reject most of the input, every reflection can lead to unexpected breakthroughs).

Absolutely on your points! This is why I'm so focused on context-setting and 'value' setting first and foremost. If players can understand what we're going for and what we think good looks like and what values inform that... then they can come to a reasonable discussion. I want us to be very transparent about that.

Sometimes the most frustrating thing is when someone's asking questions or inquiring because they want information, but you don't know what *they* want. That shit drives me insane because I feel like I'm being manipulated to give answers, or I'm not actually engaging in a dialogue - they just want to mine me for shit.

It's great at disarming people though - "tell me what you want" - but it often feels like it translates to weird action.

Instead, if we lead with our values and objectives, a player can look at those and then agree or disagree, and we can go from there. They can understand how their feedback or questions or opinions have an impact on our decisions.

*laughs* guess we´re in some kind of weird spiral there, as this threads here are basically you asking the players to ask for information without all that much context on what they really want to know...which had been my original issue when i´ve been criticising that questions without opinion don´t lead to much progress.


So more on the "lead with our values and objectives" part from my perspective then...I mean you once had stated some design values (mastery, choices, counterplay, teamplay, clarity, evolution) - but their are still 3 primary issues to me currently:

- those are kinda hard to find if you don´t already know about them in the first place, so most players on the boards will probably not have heard about them
- they still don´t offer any holesome vision of what you guys think a moba should be (especially wether it should offer a lot of strategic depth (which i currently think is the strength of lol compared to hots, dota and hon) or if it should be more action focused)
- even if one argues along those values it often feels like red responses don´t seem all that interessted in those at times
I'm having flashbacks regarding strawmen and Thresh right about now.

I can back down on my comment about Thresh from a few years back because I now agree that Thresh provides an incredible degree of safety for a co-laner without having to put himself in meaningful danger. Does that come with meaningful tradeoffs? Perhaps not. Should it? That's an interesting question.

At one point I believed the above opinion, and these days not so much. Hopefully I'm wiser and you'll allow me to grow in my knowledge of the game, much like I hope to extend the same courtesy to you. If this is just about being snarky, I'm really good at that too.

I'm not really trying to strawman anything in what I said above - I'm saying these are the basic demands of a conversation between peers. There are definitely opinions that are unique and interesting and can probably just be posed as opinions - "I understand you were going for games to be won on action rather than starvation, but it feels like that's gone too far - is that a fair assessment? Are you going to do something about this?" - that's a great way to engage and I wouldn't mind it.

Every rule you can bend, and if you want to get stuck on hard defining things then I'm not sure if that's a good use of anyone's time. How about we just be friendly?

I want to talk about the changes to minions; they scare me. What worries me is that the subtle and interesting mini game of wave control will be damaged or worst case destroyed.

It's a fascinating and subtle thing to control the minion waves, and when done successful you can set up freezes to deny CS to enemy, or make large waves that damage side lanes as you do objectives. What worries me is that the changes to minions, make them auto push which makes setting up pushes and doing freezes much harder to control.

What is the intent behind the changes, and what is your thoughts about wave manipulation and the new system?

> [{quoted}](name=Wertilq,realm=EUW,application-id=A7LBtoKc,discussion-id=ZzAaElGY,comment-id=0016,timestamp=2015-11-12T22:47:59.531+0000)
>
> I want to talk about the changes to minions; they scare me. What worries me is that the subtle and interesting mini game of wave control will be damaged or worst case destroyed.
> 
> It's a fascinating and subtle thing to control the minion waves, and when done successful you can set up freezes to deny CS to enemy, or make large waves that damage side lanes as you do objectives. What worries me is that the changes to minions, make them auto push which makes setting up pushes and doing freezes much harder to control.
> 
> What is the intent behind the changes, and what is your thoughts about wave manipulation and the new system?

As fascinating and subtle as it is, the net result is that if you're on a team with a substantial lead, it's one big factor that leads to you having a higher net gold flow than the other team provided nothing meaningful happens. You can almost guarantee you'll win the game provided you can drag it out for 15-20 minutes after it's mostly decided... and since you're ahead, avoiding fights that aren't crushingly in your favor isn't all that hard to do.

The intent for the new system is to reverse that - if nothing significant happens, the team that is behind will tend to catch up on gold. At the same time, the team that is ahead gets more opportunities to try to press their advantage. Our goal is that games that are getting out of hand either end faster or experience a comeback faster. Overall comebacks should happen at about the same rate or possibly a bit more often, but if this mechanic specifically reduces the number of comebacks, we have a lot of ways of increasing them without giving up on the advantages we're after with this system.

I don't believe that wave manipulation is totally dead - if you're just a little bit behind, slow pushes and freezes actually work better than before, since having extra minions around far outweighs the advantage - but I do realize it's likely to be more difficult and less valuable than before, at least in snowballed games. On the other hand, rotational play, objective control, and sieging become more valuable in those games.

I asked this before in another thread dedicated to this topic soley but no answer. 

Have you given any thoughts to edge cases such as ;
*people abusing their team mates to leave to increase/decrease their average team level? 

*Assuming dc's wont effect average level, games with AFKers/Trolls/Dc's being now even more impossible to win due to the inability to ever push your lane out and take objectives?

*Getting your weakest player to disconnect when you're ahead to force the enemy team out of their base?

*temporarily disconnect as support for a minute to force minion waves out everytime the enemy freezes?
Even several thousand gold down a 4 vs 5 is almost a guaranteed loss. I don't think the minion changes are enough to counteract that disadvantage.

Yeah almost always. I'm talking edge cases. I've played a lot of games where our team could easily win a 4v5 but they were turtled up inside their towers with great wave clear. Just tell your 0/6 support to dc for 10 minutes and there you have it, they leave their towers or are denied minions for the rest of the game. Then you get your support to reconnect and push with a 10,000 gold lead.

Or just temporarily disconnect every few minutes to force minion waves out everytime the enemy freezes?

The minion changes don't factor in whether or not you've DCed, so your team will tend to fall behind on average levels while you're DCed. It works exactly as if you were still present but not gaining experience.

In your internal playtests, about how long did it take for people to learn the new items and settle on builds and such, specifically for Marksmen? I think that with all of the new items, and that every ADC and most AD champions build vastly differently, that relearning builds is a fun challenge. But did the novelty ever wear off and people were able to say easily "I am playing Caitlyn, Cait has X features in her kit, and I am playing against X champions, so X item is good for this situation"?

That happens frequently and at varying speeds but the question is how often when we settle are we actually right? I think there was initially an assumption that Vayne would stick with Phantom Dancer for dueling purposes. Both the item and the champion's kit favored 1v1s but most of us came around to think it wasn't ALWAYS the right choice.  Tristana/Caitlyn were the same way with Firecannon. We got very excited about the extra range and then gravitated towards other choices.

To me, Firecannon became rather unsatisfying fast.

After thinking about it, I came to a reason for it: Firecannon feels unsatisfying because it only increases the range of a single attack (not that that is necessarily bad from a balancing PoV, far from it). This means that it truely shines in situation where you can only apply a single auto-attack. But those situations are rare.

And it is kind-of a trap on ADCs that already have a long range, like Tristana and Caitlyn. Both of those can auto-attack from relative safety already, lessening the benefit of a further range increase.

Why didn't Cass get mana buffs?

Based on our internal item purchase data - Cass didn't buy ~2+ mana potions a game which was our internal metric for mages to determine whether or not they used mana potions extensively enough to be heavily affected.

We didn't compensate based on mana consumption - but directly off whether or not they purchased it significantly.
Well question, was it because she got a first item Tear?
Huh. I am legitimately surprised.

To be fair, it was kind of an arbitrary metric.

I had trouble determining what was a good step to start with in terms of compensation - as base mana happens every recall, while MP/5 is pretty continuous.   Trying to account for an early 200 MP boost via base stats is highly imperfect.

I think the explanation for Cass is mostly because of how her 'E' mechanic refunds Mana - the better you are on Cassie, the less mana potions you need - which means that as you get better on Cass, you stop relying on mana potions and start relying on max mana sources and the 'E' restore.
True enough. Most of Cassie's mana problems happen late enough that mana pots can't really do much to stem the tide.
